sentences.sentence: President Kőrösi: This is my first time speaking to the Geneva press corps as President of the General Assembly.

Therefore, very special thanks should go for your interest in the work of the United Nations, what we are trying to achieve in the United Nations and what we're trying to change in the United Nations.
This is particularly important because we have an issue of relevance of the United Nations in the eyes of many in the world.

Let us just think about the war in Ukraine, where a permanent member of the Security Council has launched an attack, war, against its neighbor and the Security Council body that has been created many, many years back, to be the guardian of security is now blocked and paralyzed.
In the last year of conflict of the war in Ukraine, the Security Council has not been able to take any decision on this war.
Let me also try to draw your attention to another issue of global significance - the problem of the global water crisis.

We are already in the middle of the global water crisis and to address possible solutions out of this crisis, we are going to have next month, from the 22 to 24 March, the first full fledged water conference since 1977.
With the full 193 UN Members, with the full UN system and many stakeholders, private sector, civil society, academia, representatives among us to address the most difficult questions and issues.
We need to change how we deal with water.
We need to change the world in terms of water management.
You may know that for many in the world, the climate crisis is felt as a water crisis.
And that in fact 80 per cent of the impacts of climate change

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

text: President Kőrösi: This is my first time speaking to the Geneva press corps as President of the General Assembly. Therefore, very special thanks should go for your interest in the work of the United Nations, what we are trying to achieve in the United Nations and what we’re trying to change in the United Nations. This is particularly important because we have an issue of relevance of the United Nations in the eyes of many in the world. Let us just think about the war in Ukraine, where a permanent member of the Security Council has launched an attack, war, against its neighbor and the Security Council body that has been created many, many years back, to be the guardian of security is now blocked and paralyzed. In the last year of conflict of the war in Ukraine, the Security Council has not been able to take any decision on this war. Let me also try to draw your attention to another issue of global significance – the problem of the global water crisis. We are already in the middle of the global water crisis and to address possible solutions out of this crisis, we are going to have next month, from the 22 to 24 March, the first full fledged water conference since 1977. With the full 193 UN Members, with the full UN system and many stakeholders, private sector, civil society, academia, representatives among us to address the most difficult questions and issues. We need transformative solutions. We need to change how we deal with water. We need to change the world in terms of water management. You may know that for many in the world, the climate crisis is felt as a water crisis. And that in fact 80 per cent of the impacts of climate change
